questions.text: The following picture shows the composition of solute in the urine and plasma sample of 3 patients. Identify the true statement.

choices.text: A shows negative free water clearance, B is isotonic, C is positive free water clearance
A shows positive free water clearance B is isotonic C is positive free water clearance
A shows positive free water clearance B is isotonic C is negative free water clearance
A shows negative free water clearance B is isotonic C is negative free water clearance

questions.solution:
Patient A shows positive free water clearance B is isotonic C shows negative free water clearance.

Free water clearance is defined as the amount of solute-free water generated by the kidneys, either when dilute urine or when concentrated urine is formed.

Patient A has positive free-water clearance, since excess water is being excreted (dilute urine).

Patient C has negative free-water clearance, since excess solutes are being removed and water is being conserved (concentrated urine).

questions.text: Which of the following is true about  the nature of the sensory receptor given below:
questions.solution:
The sensory receptor shown in the above image is Pacinian corpuscle. The Pacinian corpuscle is a rapidly adapting receptor and is an encapsulated receptor.

When a stimulus of the same strength is continuously given to a sensory receptor, the frequency of the action potentials generated by the receptor gradually decreases. This phenomenon is known as receptor adaptation. Depending on whether the receptor stops responding to a stimulus rapidly or slowly, they are classified as rapidly adapting (phasic) or slow adapting receptors (tonic).

Related Pearl: Slow vs rapidly adapting receptors

Slow adapting Rapidly adapting receptors
Also called tonic receptors Also called phasic receptors
They are expanded on free nerve endings. They are encapsulated nerve endings.
Responds to steady stimulus Respond to rate of change of stimulus
With steady stimulus, tonic receptors keep responding steadily. With steady stimulus, receptor responds initially but stops or adapts rapidly.
Examples: Merkel's disc, Ruffini's end organs, Joint capsule, Muscle spindle, Golgi tendon organs Examples: Pacinian corpuscle, Meissner's corpuscles, Hair end organs

questions.text: The diagnosis of an infant, presenting with the defect shown in the image below is:
questions.solution:
Cloacal exstrophy(CE) is a rare condition affecting the infant in-utero. Here, the bladder and the ileocecal junction of the bowel are open to the exterior and the hindgut is truncated (giving tusks on the face of the elephant appearance)  and terminates in the perineum. 

Four features of Cloacal exstrophy are frequently found together and is referred to as OEIS Complex.

Omphalocele

Exstrophy of the bladder and rectum (cloacal exstrophy)

Imperforate hymen

Spinal defects

questions.text: An infant is brought to the pediatric OPD with clinical findings as shown in the image. Further examination shows that the child has a loss of developmental milestones, truncal hypotonia, and failure to thrive. Which of the following enzymes is defective in this child?
questions.solution:
The given image reveals an infant with sparse and kinky hair. This, along with loss of developmental milestones and truncal hypotonia, strongly suggests a diagnosis of Menkes disease, which is caused by defective lysyl oxidase. 

Menkes disease results from a deficiency of lysyl oxidase co-factor i.e copper. This is due to a defect in the ATP7A gene, which prevents the absorption of copper from the intestine.

Note :

  • ATP7A mutation: Menkes disease - X-linked recessive
  • ATP7B mutation: Wilson's disease - Autosomal recessive

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: A patient has normal vertical saccades. On attempted left gaze as shown in the image below, the patient develops left jerk nystagmus.  Where is the most likely location of the lesion?
questions.solution:
The most likely location of the lesion according to the given clinical scenario and the image is the right medial longitudinal fasciculus.

The image depicts an attempted left gaze and concludes that there is an adduction deficit in the right eye. This causes jerk nystagmus in the abducting left eye. 

This is most likely due to a lesion of the medial longitudinal fasciculus (MLF) ipsilateral to the side of the adduction deficit. Hence, this is a case of a right MLF lesion or Right Internuclear Ophthalmoplegia (INO).

questions.text: An ophthalmologist tests a particular phenomenon using the instrument shown below. Which of the following statements is false regarding the same?

choices.text: The phenomenon is a physiological one
Frontal lobe controls the slow pursuit movement
Reversal of optokinetic nystagmus, in congenital motor nystagmus

questions.solution:
The given image shows an optokinetic drum used to elicit optokinetic nystagmus (OKN). The parieto-occipital lobe controls the slow pursuit component, whereas the frontal lobes control the saccadic component.

OKN is normal physiological nystagmus in response to motion/continuously moving objects. It occurs in response to a repetitive visual stimulus moved across the visual field. The slow phase occurs in the direction of the moving stimulus; the fast phase occurs as a saccadic refixation movement in the opposite direction. In patients with congenital motor nystagmus, a reversal of the OKN response may occur. An OKN response elicited in a person who feigns visual loss indicates that visual input is present and is a malingerer.

questions.text: The most common triggering factor of the given condition is ________
questions.solution:
The given image shows characteristic target lesions of erythema multiforme. This most commonly occurs following a herpes simplex virus infection.

The common triggers are:

  • Herpes simplex infection
  • Mycoplasma infection
  • Bacterial infections
  • Fungal infections
  • Vaccinations
  • Malignancy- carcinoma, lymphoma, leukemia
  • Drugs- sulfonamides, rifampicin, penicillins, hydantoin derivatives
  • Miscellaneous- lupus erythematosus (Rowell Syndrome), sarcoidosis, polyarteritis nodosa

Erythema multiforme is best regarded as a self‐limiting cytotoxic dermatitis resulting from cell‐mediated hypersensitivity.

It presents clinically with a spectrum of macular, papular, or urticarial lesions, as well as the classic acral iris or ‘target lesions’.

Target lesions are less than 3 cm in diameter, rounded, and have three zones:

  1. Central area of dusky erythema or purpura
  2. Middle paler zone of edema
  3. Outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge

Lesions may involve the palms and the trunk. Oral and genital mucosal membranes lesions are associated with erosions

The image below shows target lesions.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the instrument in the image?

choices.text: It is used to test macular function
It is used to measure vertical, horizontal tropias, and phorias
It cannot be used to  measure cyclodeviation
It is based on diplopic projection

questions.solution:
The image shows a Maddox rod.

Cyclodeviation is measured with the double Maddox rod test.

The Maddox rod test uses a specially constructed device consisting of a series of parallel cylinders that converts a point source of light into a line image.

It can be used to test for horizontal and vertical deviations, and when used in conjunction with another Maddox rod, for cyclodeviations.

questions.text: A man who regularly uses contact lenses comes with complaints of blurred vision and ocular pain. Examination shows radial keratoneuritis as seen below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above presentation of blurred vision and pain, along with the findings of a radial keratoneuritis and ring lesion (seen in the image), suggests a probable diagnosis of acanthamoeba keratitis. 

It is caused by Acanthamoeba spp which are free-living protozoa found in soil, freshwater, and the upper respiratory tract. Contact lens wearers are the most prone to this infection.

Patients complain of blurring of vision and pain is often disproportionate to examination. There are characteristic perineural infiltrates, otherwise known as radial keratoneuritis, are pathognomonic and can be seen during early infection. As the infiltrates grow, they gradually coalesce to form the typical ring abscess.

Staining of the corneal scraping using periodic acid-Schiff or calcofluor white as well as culture is done to diagnose the disease. 

Management includes topical amoebecides, analgesics for pain, as well as debridement of the involved epithelium. Therapeutic keratoplasty is done for resistant cases. 

 The below image shows a hypopyon and typical ring abscess of amebic keratitis.

 

Other options:

Option A: Staphylococcal keratitis usually presents as photophobia, blurred vision, mucopurulent discharge and focal and well-defined white/yellowish-white infiltrate. There are features of anterior uveitis with hypopyon and keratic precipitates.

Option B: Candidal keratitis would present as a typical yellow-white densely suppurative infiltrate. Features of anterior uveitis can also be seen here. 

Option C: Herpes simplex keratitis presents as ocular discomfort, photophobia, and decreased visual acuity. HSV can cause characteristic epithelial (dendritic/geographic) keratitis or disciform keratitis.

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs.

questions.text: An elderly lady presented to the clinic following a head injury. She exhibited an unsteady drunk-like gait while entering the examination room. She also had nodding movements of the head and nystagmus. Which region of the cerebellum marked in the following image was most likely affected by the bleed?
questions.solution:
Area marked as 4 is most likely affected by the bleed, i.e., vestibulocerebellum (or flocculonodular lobe).

Cerebellum has three parts based on function.

  • Vestibulocerebellum (or flocculonodular lobe): This lobe is the oldest part of the cerebellum. It has vestibular connections concerned with equilibrium and eye movements. Therefore, in lesions of the flocculonodular lobe, patients will have gait ataxia, nodding of the head and axial body (known as titubation), and nystagmus.
  • Spinocerebellum: This is the region that receives proprioceptive inputs from the body as well as from the motor cortex. By comparing plan from the motor cortex with performance, it smoothens and coordinates movements that are ongoing.
  • Cerebrocerebellum: This is the newest part of the cerebellum. They coordinate with the motor cortex in planning and programming movements. Patients will have dysmetria, dysarthria, dysdiadochokinesis, hypotonia, or intention tremor in one or both extremities. 

Lesions in the cerebellum may present with the following symptoms:

  • Wide-based, drunk-like unsteady, stumbling gait, which is also called staggering gait
  • Ataxia - Defects in movement and coordination
  • Dysdiadokinesia - Inability to perform alternating movements (e.g. supination, pronation) at a fast pace
  • Dysequilibrium - Loss of balance
  • Nystagmus
  • Intention tremor - This tremor is not present during rest, but is present during voluntary movements of limbs. The tremor increases when it reaches the target object of its movement.
  • Speech - Slurred or scanning
  • Hypotonia

questions.text: An obstetrician performs an aspiration of the endometrial cavity in a woman with complaints of a missed period 2 weeks back. Identify the following instrument. What is the procedure it is used for?
questions.solution:
The instrument is Karman’s cannula and  syringe, which is also used for menstrual regulation.

Menstrual regulation is the aspiration of the endometrial cavity within 14 days of a missed period in a woman with a previous normal cycle.

Under aseptic precautions, the cervix may be gently dilated using 4-5 mm size dilators. Then 5-6mm Karman’s cannula is inserted and attached to a 50ml syringe for suction. The cannula is rotated, and pushed in and out with gentle strokes.

This procedure is contraindicated in advanced pregnancy and in the presence of local pelvic inflammation. The drawbacks of the procedure include a missed implanted zygote or an unrecognized ectopic pregnancy.

This procedure is not commonly done anymore.

questions.text: A farmer from the sub-Himalayan belt had a thorn prick injury a year back and developed a warty, verrucous growth at the site of prick. A skin biopsy sample was taken and sent for histopathological examination. The characteristic microscopic body as shown in the image was seen. Which of the following could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of a slowly spreading warty, verrucous lesion following a thorn prick injury and the histopathological image showing medlar bodies is suggestive of chromoblastomycosis.

Chromoblastomycosis (chromomycosis) is a subcutaneous mycotic infection that is usually caused by traumatic inoculation. Over months to years, the primary lesion becomes verrucous and wart-like with extension along the draining lymphatics. 

Histologically, the lesions are granulomatous and the dark sclerotic bodies may be seen within leukocytes or giant cells called medlar/copper penny bodies.

questions.text: A 25 year old man involved in a fight, injured his finger and the deformity is shown in the following image. X-ray is normal. The most appropriate management at this stage is:

choices.text: Surgical repair of the flexor tendon

questions.solution:
Based on the mechanism of injury and the deformity characterized by flexion at the distal interphalangeal joint, along with a normal radiograph, the likely diagnosis is mallet finger, which is managed by splinting the finger in hyperextension.

Mallet finger, also known as baseball finger, occurs when there is a sudden passive flexion of the distal interphalangeal joint, causing avulsion of the extensor tendon from its insertion at the base of the distal phalanx.

The terminal joint is held in a flexed position, and the patient is unable to straighten it. However, passive movement of the finger remains normal.

As it occurs due to soft tissue injury, a radiograph will not show any bony abnormality, unless it is associated with an avulsion fracture.

Mallet finger without bone injury is treated with a plastic splint, keeping the DIP joint hyperextended for eight weeks, followed by four weeks of night splinting.

The following image shows splinting of the mallet finger:

Surgery is considered only if there is a large fragment (>50%) and subluxation of the DIP joint.

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: Test shown in the image is useful for the detection of ________________
questions.solution:
The test shown in the photograph is rapid plasma reagin test used to detect Treponema pallidum.

RPR test is one of the nonspecific tests  commonly used to screen the population for syphilis. The RPR test measures IgM and IgG antibodies to lipoidal material released from damaged host cells as well as to lipoprotein-like material, and possibly cardiolipin released from the treponemes.

Antigen used in RPR Test:

RPR antigen contains cardiolipin, lecithin, cholesterol, 10% choline chloride, EDTA, charcoal etc in buffer. The test uses the VDRL antigen containing fine carbon particle ,which makes result more clear cut and evident to naked eye.

Syphilis is caused by Treponema pallidum, a spirochete bacillus. It is a sexually transmitted infection. Intrauterine transmission can lead to congenital syphilis.

It shows corkscrew motility which can be demonstrated by darkfield microscopy. 

Treponema can be stained by silver impregnation methods. 

  • Fontana's method is used on smear
  • Levaditi's method is used for tissue sections

The clinical manifestations of syphilis include:

Primary syphilis: The typical primary chancre usually begins as a single painless papule that rapidly becomes eroded and usually becomes indurated, with a characteristic cartilaginous consistency on palpation of the edge and base of the ulcer.

Inguinal lymphadenopathy is bilateral and may occur with anal as well as with genital chancres. The chancre generally heals within 4–6 weeks (range, 2–12 weeks), but lymphadenopathy may persist for months.

Secondary syphilis: The various features include mucocutaneous or cutaneous lesions and generalized nontender lymphadenopathy. macular, papular, papulosquamous, and occasionally pustular syphilides. Other features of secondary syphilis include sore throat, fever, weight loss, malaise, anorexia, headache, and meningismus. Ocular findings associated with secondary (or later/ unknown-stage) syphilis include pupillary abnormalities and optic neuritis as well as the classic iritis or uveitis.

Latent syphilis: Early latent syphilis is limited to the first year after infection, whereas late latent syphilis is defined as that of 1 year’s duration (or of unknown duration). T. pallidum may still seed the bloodstream intermittently during the latent stage, and latent syphilis in a pregnant woman may infect the fetus in utero. 

Neurosyphilis:  The major clinical categories of symptomatic neurosyphilis include meningeal, meningovascular, and parenchymatous syphilis.

Cardiovascular syphilis: Cardiovascular involvement results in uncomplicated aortitis, aortic regurgitation, saccular aneurysm (usually of the ascending aorta), or coronary ostial stenosis.

Congenital syphilis: The earliest manifestations of congenital syphilis include rhinitis, or “snuffles”; mucocutaneous lesions, bone changes, including periostitis detectable by x-ray examination of long bones; hepatosplenomegaly,  lymphadenopathy , anemia
, jaundice,  thrombocytopenia, and leukocytosis.

Serologic tests for syphilis recommended by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC):

  1. Screening or diagnosis (RPR or VDRL),
  2. Quantitative measurement of antibody to assess clinical syphilis activity or to monitor response to therapy (RPR or VDRL)
  3. Confirmation of a syphilis diagnosis in a patient with a reactive RPR or VDRL test (FTA-ABS, TPHA, EIA/CIA)

Treatment of syphilis is with 2.4 million units of intramuscular benzathine penicillin.

Related Pearl: Syphilis - Diagnostic Serology

Nontreponemal tests (VDRL, RPR)

VDRL- Venereal disease Research Laboratory test

RPR- Rapid Plasma Reagin test

  • Quantitative tests(titres)
  • Reagin antibody tests; based on cardiolipin antigen
  • VDRL can be used to test CSF whereas RPR cannot be used
  • RPR does not require preheating of serum unlike VDRL
  • VDRL requires light microscope for interpretation whereas RPR can be read macroscopically
  • Decrease in titers confirms treatment
  • Sensitivity of RPR(86%)>VDRL(76%) in primary syphilis

Treponemal Tests

FTA-ABS- Fluorescent Treponemal Antibody Absorption test

TPI-Treponema pallidum immobilization test

TPPA-Treponema pallidum particle agglutination assay

TPHA-Treponema pallidum haemagglutination test

EIA-Enzyme-linked ImmunoAssay

  • Detect antibody to treponemal antigens
  • Qualitative tests
  • Greater sensitivity in early infection
  • Positive even after treatment hence cannot be used to detect reinfection.
  • First test to be positive: FTA-ABS
  • Most specific: TPHA,TPPA, EIA

questions.text: Mr. Kumar, a 60-year-old male had pain in the eye and visual disturbances 2 days after undergoing cataract surgery. The image of his eye is given below. The probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The image shows a picture of inflammation and hypopyon. This, along with the presentation of pain and visual disturbances acutely after cataract surgery suggest that the patient has developed endophthalmitis.

Endophthalmitis:

  • Cardinal features are pain, conjunctival or lid injection, and swelling and decrease in vision.
  • Postoperative endophthalmitis patient classically presents acutely within 7 days after surgery with inflammation of the eye, corneal edema, and a hypopyon, due to the pouring of exudates in the vitreous cavity, anterior chamber and posterior chamber.
  • The intravitreal injection of antibiotics has become the primary method of administration in the treatment of endophthalmitis. Other modalities of treatment include:
    • Topical antibiotic
    • Cycloplegia
    • Oral steroids
    • Pars plana vitrectomy

Toxic anterior segment syndrome is characterized by diffuse limbus-to-limbus corneal edema and anterior segment inflammation. The following points differentiate it from endophthalmitis

  • Vitreous inflammation is rare (vitreous inflammation present in endophthalmitis).
  • No pain/ little pain unless the IOP is very high. (Pain more often indicates endophthalmitis).
  • A fixed, dilated pupil–often with spotty or diffuse areas of iris atrophy. (Not seen in endophthalmitis)
  • Extremely high IOP early in the postoperative period is an unusual finding for endophthalmitis and points toward a diagnosis of TASS.
  • A therapeutic response to topical steroids is clearly present for several days in TASS, unlike in endophthalmitis, where the patient's condition worsens even after the application of topical steroids.

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.solution:
The anomaly shown in the image is caudal regression which is mostly associated with maternal diabetes.

questions.text: The blood smear slides (A) and (B) prepared from a patient suspected with malaria are shown below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding these tests?

choices.text: Slide (A) is used for estimating the parasite concentration
Slide (A) has been air dried for 10 minutes
Slide (B) cannot be used for detecting the species of the parasite
Jaswant Singh Bhattacharya stain is used for both

questions.solution:
Slide (A) is a thin blood smear and slide (B) is a thick blood smear. Thin blood smears (slide A) are not used for estimating parasite concentration. They are used to detect the species of parasite.

Microscopy is the best method for the diagnosis of malaria due to its high sensitivity and specificity. Jaswant Singh Battacharya (JSB) stain is used for staining both thick and thin smears.

Thick smear is used to detect infection and estimate parasite concentration. The correct thickness is the thickness through which a newsprint is barely visible. It is prepared by slow-drying for 30 minutes, which leads to hemolysis and distortion of the plasmodia morphology. Hence, species cannot be detected.

Thin smear is used to identify the particular infecting species of Plasmodium. It is prepared by air drying for 10 minutes and fixed in methanol. Thus, the plasmodia morphology is not distorted.

questions.text: A patient with leprosy, who has completed a course of multi-drug therapy, presents with complaints of developing painful, tender, and raised lesions on his forehead recently as shown in the image below. What is the first-line treatment for him?

choices.text: Restart multi drug therapy and start thalidomide
Restart multi drug therapy and start prednisolone

questions.solution:
The presence of new erythematous and tender subcutaneous nodules in a patient with leprosy indicates that he has developed type II lepra reaction. It is also known as Erythema Nodosum Leprosum (ENL) and the first line of treatment is prednisolone.

Multi-drug therapy (MDT) should not be restarted in patients who develop lepra reactions after the completion of treatment.

Prednisolone is started at a dose of 40 mg per day and gradually tapered by 5 mg every 2 weeks. 'Prednisolone card' is given when treatment is started. If the patient becomes steroid-dependent, then clofazimine is added.

The  key targets of the Global Leprosy Strategy 2021-2023 announced by WHO (Accelerating towards a leprosy-free world) are:

  • 120 countries reporting zero new autochthonous cases.
  • 70% reduction in the annual number of new cases detected.
  • 90% reduction in rate per million population of new cases with Grade 2 disability.
  • 90% reduction in rate per million children of new child cases with leprosy.

The current goal is the elimination of leprosy.

Inflammation of existing skin lesions (red, painful edematous skin lesions) that may ulcerate

New lesions may occur (rare)

Neuritis and Nerve abscesses (red, painful inflamed nerves)

New, erythematous and tender, subcutaneous and dermal nodules that are widely distributed over extremities and face

Existing lesions do not change
No systemic involvement Systemic symptoms present - fever, myalgias, arthralgias, anorexia, keratitis, iritis, nephritis, synovitis, orchitis, lymphadenopathy

Treatment:

Supportive therapy for mild reactions with NSAIDs

In case of severe reactions with neuritis and eye lesions- Oral corticosteroids

(Drug of Choice)

Nerve Abscess - Additional surgical drainage

Other drugs: Clofazimine, Cyclosporine

Treatment:

Oral Corticosteroids - First-line drug

Clofazimine (Steroid dependent ENL)

Thalidomide -most effective but not used first due to various side effects

questions.text: A 5-year-old child requires bronchodilator therapy. You attach the device shown below to the pressurized metered-dose inhaler for ease of use. Which of the following is false about this device?

choices.text: Decreases the deposition of drug on the oropharynx
Increases the delivery of drug to lower airways
Increases the incidence of oropharyngeal candidiasis
Systemic absorption of drugs is unaffected

questions.solution:
The given image is of a spacer device. It decreases the incidence of oropharyngeal candidiasis and other propellant-mediated oropharyngeal adverse effects like dysphonia that occur with the use of a pMDI.

Spacers reduce the velocity and size of particles entering the upper airways. This reduces the amount of drug that impinges on the oropharynx and increases the proportion of drug inhaled into lower airways. The systemic absorption is unchanged by the use of a spacer.

Spacer devices are useful in delivering inhaled drugs to children who are not able to use a pMDI alone but can also be used by adults for better drug delivery. The image below shows the use of a spacer device with a face mask which is preferred in children younger than 3 years of age.

The various devices used for the delivery of inhalational drugs are:

  • Pressurized metered-dose inhalers - Drugs are propelled from a canister in the pMDI with the aid of a propellant. These devices are convenient, portable, and typically deliver 50–200 doses of a drug
  • Dry powder inhalers - these devices scatter the drug into a fine powder that is dispersed by air turbulence on inhalation. DPIs have been developed to deliver drugs such as insulin, but the dosing is inconsistent. Children <7 years find it difficult to use a DPI. 
  • Nebulizers: Two types of nebulizer are available -
    • Jet nebulizers that are driven by a stream of gas (air or oxygen)
    • Ultrasonic nebulizers that use a rapidly vibrating piezoelectric crystal and thus do not require a source of compressed gas.

The nebulizers deliver much higher drug doses as compared pMDIs. These are useful in:

  • Treating acute exacerbations of asthma and COPD
  • Extreme airway obstruction (severe COPD)
  • Delivering inhaled drugs to infants and small children who cannot use the other inhalation devices
  • Administering drugs such as antibiotics in relatively high doses

questions.text: The skull X-ray of a patient who presented with bone pains is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The radiograph shows cotton wool skull which is diagnostic of Paget’s disease.

Radiological features during the early phase of this disease include osteolytic (lucent) regions which is later followed by coarse trabeculae and bony enlargement. Sclerotic changes occur much later in the disease process. The lesions seen are:

  • Osteoporosis circumscripta: large, well-defined lytic lesion
  • Cotton wool appearance: mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions of the skull
  • Diploic widening: both inner and outer calvarial tables are involved, with the former usually more extensively affected
  • Tam o'Shanter sign: frontal bone enlargement, with the appearance of the skull falling over the facial bones, like a Tam o' Shanter hat.

The image below shows cotton wool appearance on skull X-ray:

The image given below shows the Tam O Shanter hat sign, with the hat it looks like:

questions.text: In the following pressure-volume loop diagram of left ventricle, the mitral valve will close at the point:
questions.solution:
The closure of the mitral valve corresponds to point 2, which marks the beginning of the isovolumetric contraction phase.

 The pressure-volume curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

  • Point 1 - Mitral valve opens
  • Point 2 - Mitral valve closes
  • Point 3 - Aortic valve opens
  • Point 4 - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling:  

  • In the given diagram, the period of filling lasts from point 1 to point 2.
  • At point A, the volume of blood present in the left ventricle is the end-systolic volume which corresponds to about 50 ml. It is at this point that the mitral valve opens and the venous blood flows into the left ventricle from the left atrium.
  • At point B, the end of the period of filling—the amount of blood present in the left ventricle is called the end-diastolic volume which corresponds to about 120 ml. It is at this point that the mitral valve closes.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction:

  • In the given diagram, the period of isovolumetric contraction lasts from point 2 to point 3.
  • At point B, the mitral valve closes and the volume of the ventricle does not change as all the valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle continues to rise.
  • At point C the ventricular pressure increases to become equal to the pressure in the aorta (80 mm Hg) and then the aortic valve opens.

Phase III: Period of ejection

  • In the given diagram, the period of ejection lasts from point 3 to point 4.
  • At point C, the aortic valve opens and the volume of the ventricle decreases as the blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.
  • The systolic pressure continues to rise as the ventricle contracts.
  • At point D the aortic valve closes.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

  • In the given diagram, the period of relaxation lasts from point 4 to point 1.
  • At point D, the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. 
  • This decrease in intraventricular pressure occurs without any change in volume.
  • At point A, the ventricle now has an end-systolic volume of 50 ml of blood similar to the beginning of the cycle.

questions.text: While on rounds in the psychiatry ward, you observe a patient standing still near his bed. On trying to move his hand you feel a slight resistance, and the patient remained in the final position for the next half hour. What feature is observed here?
questions.solution:
The method as shown demonstrates waxy flexibility, which is a feature of catatonia. In this, parts of the body can be placed in positions that will be maintained for long periods of time, even if very uncomfortable. The limbs are flexible like wax and a slight resistance is felt while moving them. 

Features of Catatonia:

  1. Mutism- complete absence of speech.
  2. Rigidity- maintenance of a rigid posture against efforts.
  3. Negativism- an apparently motiveless resistance to all commands.
  4. Posturing- voluntary assumption of an inappropriate and often bizarre posture for long periods of time, against gravity.
  5. Waxy flexibility- the patient's limbs can be manipulated to move in any position (flexible like wax), which is then retained by the patient for long periods of time, even if uncomfortable.
  6. Stupor- akinesis (no movement) with mutism with relative preservation of conscious awareness. 
  7. Echolalia- repetition of phrases or words heard.
  8. Echopraxia- repetition of actions observed.
  9. Ambitendency- tendency to act in opposing ways or directions because of conflicting impulses. e.g. on asking to take out the tongue, the tongue is slightly protruded but taken back again.
  10. Gegenhalten- when subjects involuntary resist passive movements. The resistance is directly proportional to the force applied. Also called oppositional paratonia.
  11. Mannerism- repetition of normal movements but inappropriately. They are purposeful. E.g., repeatedly saluting the people around.
  12. Stereotypy- repetitive, odd, purposeless movements. E.g., making strange movements of fingers repeatedly.
  13. Automatic obedience- commands are followed automatically, irrespective of their nature.

questions.text: A child was brought to the clinic for evaluation of recurrent UTI. Ultrasound revealed a dilated renal pelvis. Intravenous urogram done is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and intravenous urogram showing a "drooping lily" sign point to a diagnosis of a duplex kidney. 

It refers to the presence of duplicated ureters or collecting systems. This is due to the incomplete fusion of the upper and lower pole of the kidney. Duplex kidneys have two separate pelvicalyceal systems draining single renal parenchyma.

The lower pole ureter is normally inserted into the bladder. However, the upper pole ureter has an ectopic insertion. It crosses the lower pole ureter to open inferior and medial to the normal site of insertion (Weigert–Meyer rule). This results in reflux and incontinence.

Option B: In retrocaval ureter, the IVC presses on the right ureter as it lies behind the IVC. Intravenous urogram shows reversed ‘J’/ fish hook ureter.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient presents to the OPD with high fever, chest pain, dyspnoea, and hemoptysis. The patient also complains of watery diarrhea. The direct fluorescent antibody stained film of his pleural fluid is given below. Identify the most likely etiologic agent.
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette and the image showing fluorescent organisms in the direct fluorescent antibody (DFA) stained film of pleural fluid suggest the diagnosis of Legionnaire's disease, caused by Legionella pneumophila.

Two distinct clinical patterns of legionellosis have been identified:

  • Legionnaires' disease presents with fever, non-productive cough, and dyspnea rapidly progressing to pneumonia if left untreated. Patients can also develop a hyponatremia. Diarrhea and encephalopathy are also common. It is often included in the differential diagnosis of atypical pneumonia. Atypical pneumonia is also caused by: 
    • Chlamydia pneumonia
    • Chlamydia psittaci
    • Mycoplasma pneumonia
    • Coxiella burnetii
    • Viruses such as influenza virus, adenovirus and respiratory syncytial virus
  • Pontiac fever is a milder, non-fatal, influenza-like illness with fever, chills, myalgia, and headache.

Other options:

Option A: Chlamydia pneumonia causes pharyngitis, sinusitis, bronchitis, and pneumonia. It has also been associated with adult onset asthma. Outbreaks have been reported in closed communities. Real-time PCR is used for its diagnosis.

Option C: Haemophilus influenzae typically causes pneumonia in infants. While the primary infections occur due to capsulated strains, bronchopneumonia may occur as a secondary infection due to non-capsulated strains. Gram stain and culture are used for diagnosis.

Option D: Klebsiella pneumonia causes fatal pneumonia, which occurs in middle -aged or older persons with risk factors such as alcoholism, chronic bronchopulmonary disease or diabetes mellitus. Gram stain and culture are used for diagnosis.

questions.text:
A first-year psychiatry resident gets a call regarding one of his patients who has been brought to the ER with high-grade fever and pharyngitis. The patient was started on clozapine two weeks back for treatment-resistant schizophrenia. His oral examination reveals the following picture. What would be the appropriate management?
  1. Stop clozapine
  2. Reduce the dose of clozapine
  3. Administer granulocyte colony-stimulating factor
  4. Switch to another antipsychotic medication
  5. Give antibiotics
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of high-grade fever and pharyngitis and the simultaneous development of oral ulcers (image) in a patient on clozapine is suggestive of drug-induced agranulocytosis. The treatment is to stop clozapine immediately, administer granulocyte colony-stimulating factor (G-CSF), and start empirical antibiotics.

Agranulocytosis is a rare, but fatal complication of clozapine. It is defined as an absolute neutrophil count (ANC) < 500/mm3, or white blood cell (WBC) count < 2000/mm3. It can initially manifest as a local infection with high-grade fever, sore throat, oral and perianal ulcerations.

These symptoms appear rapidly within days to weeks following initiation of drug therapy.

Clozapine is generally considered to be more effective than other antipsychotic drugs and is often used in treatment-resistant schizophrenia (poor treatment response to 2 or more antipsychotic drugs). Hence, a switch from clozapine to another (less effective) antipsychotic drug is not done in a patient with drug-induced agranulocytosis.

questions.text: What is the least likely cause for the finding shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows xanthelasma palpebrarum. They are seen in: 

  • Familial hypercholesterolemia
  • Type III hyperlipoproteinemia (broad beta disease)
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis (chronic cholestasis)

They are not seen in type I hyperlipoproteinemia (familial chylomicronemia).

Xanthelasmas most commonly affect the upper eyelids and the area around the medial canthus. They are relatively soft on palpation and range from pale yellow to yellow‐orange in color.

questions.text: An elderly lady presents with this skin lesion over her ear that has been there for many years without any significant visible change. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given description of a pigmented lesion on the ear present in an elderly individual over many years is typical of Lentigo maligna or Hutchinson’s melanotic freckle.

  • This type of melanoma presents as a flat, brown or black, irregularly shaped lesion which grows slowly over months and years on chronically sun-exposed areas of the skin (e.g. the face, neck, forearms) in the elderly.
  • This early intraepidermal phase is known as lentigo maligna (Hutchinson’s melanotic freckle; melanosis circumscripta precancerous of Dubreuilh).
  • After radial growth phase of 10-15 years in the epidermis, the vertical growth phase of the invasive disease may occur indicating progression to Lentigo maligna melanoma.

Other options:

  • Nodular melanoma: These type of melanomas present as rather regular, symmetrical, elevated, dome‐shaped or more rarely polypoid or sometimes pedunculated lesion with colors ranging from black, dark brown to red. They are fast-growing and ulceration and bleeding are common.
  • Superficial Spreading Melanoma: Melanoma presents like an atypical naevus, i.e. a flat pigmented macule which progressively becomes more and more irregular in shape and color. There is no preference for sun-exposed areas. 
  • Acral Lentiginous Melanoma: The initial presentation is of a discrete light brown or black macule, often described as a ‘dirty‐like stain’, with indistinct borders on the soles of patients usually aged over 60 years. At later stages, a nodule or ulceration can develop.

Related Pearl: Breslow’s Classification of Malignant Melanoma

Breslow's classification of malignant melanoma:

Stage Depth
Stage I ≤ 0.75mm
Stage II 0.76 mm - 1.50mm
Stage III 1.51 mm - 4 mm
Stage IV >4 mm

 

TNM staging based on the thickness of invasion according to AJCC:

  • T1 - ≤1.0 mm
  • T2 - 1.01-2.0 mm
  • T3 - 2.01-4.0 mm
  • T4 - >4.0 mm

questions.text: A 4-month-old boy presents with hypotonia, seizures, and failure to thrive.  The mother reports that his hair started to appear short, lusterless, and thin when he was 2-months-old. A trichogram of his scalp hair is as shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows pili torti seen in Menke's syndrome or trichopoliodystrophy or steely hair disease.

Pili torti refers to hair showing 180-degree twists under the microscope. Scalp and eyebrow hair appear short, sparse, lustreless, tangled, and depigmented. Hair changes can be the first sign of disease at 1–2 months of age.

It is an X‐linked recessive disorder. At 2–3 months of age, children with Menke's disease present with: 

  • Loss of developmental milestones
  • Hypotonia
  • Seizures
  • Failure to thrive
  • Cherubic appearance - depressed nasal bridge, pudgy cheeks, ‘cupids bow’ upper lip, and doughy skin.

Option A: In kwashiorkor, hair develops a lustreless, red‐brown color that may show alternation with more normal color; this so‐called ‘flag sign’ corresponds to alternating periods of significant undernutrition and improved nutrition.

Option B: Selenium deficiency presents as brittle hair and may be associated with exfoliative dermatitis on the scalp.

Option D: In zinc deficiency, hair is dry and brittle, and large areas of alopecia may arise.

Note :
Defect in ATP7A gene causes Menkes disease, X-linked recessive disorder whereas, defect in ATP7B gene causes Wilson's disease, Autosomal recessive disorder.

Related Pearl: Menkes disease

questions.text: Which disease is caused by the following parasite?
questions.solution:
The image shows crab louse or Pthirus pubis that causes pediculosis pubis. It has a distinctive squat body, and the second and third pairs of legs carry heavy, pincer‐like claws. 

This louse commonly infests pubic hair (most common), as well as hairs of the abdomen, chest, legs, arms, and eyelashes. Scalp hair is uninvolved due to its high density. This is often transmitted sexually and by close contact.

Blue colored macules on the trunk and inner aspects of thighs are seen called maculae ceruleae.

Treatment is with 1% permethrin and oral ivermectin.
(Infestation of the eyelashes with nits is treated with permethrin 5% cream)

questions.text: Calculate the therapeutic index of a drug whose dose-response curves are plotted as shown below:
questions.solution:
The therapeutic index is 4.

In the above graph,

Median lethal dose (LD50) = 400

Median effective dose (ED50) = 100

Therapeutic index (TI) = LD50/ED50.

Hence,

Therapeutic index (TI ) = 400/100 = 4

Clinically, the therapeutic range bound by the dose that produces the minimal therapeutic effect and the dose that produces the maximal acceptable adverse effect is more relevant.

questions.text: A 36-year-old HIV-positive man on cART is presented with the following finding. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of fat redistribution resulting in the classic buffalo hump appearance. Nelfinavir is the most likely cause.

It is a protease inhibitor and its chronic administration can result in fat redistribution and metabolic syndrome. 

Note: Atazanavir has the least propensity to cause lipodystrophy and metabolic syndrome.

questions.text: Which organization does the image given below stand for?

choices.text: National Programme for Control of Blindness
National Programme for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment

questions.solution: The symbol stands for National Programme for Control of Blindness and Visual Impairment (NPCBVI), which was previously called the National Programme for Control of Blindness.

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman was rushed to the casualty of a maternity hospital due to imminent delivery. It resulted in a stillborn baby as shown in the picture below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an occipital bone defect with retroflexion of the neck and trunk, which is typical of iniencephaly. Inion is the tip of the external occipital protuberance and this defect comes under the spectrum of neural tube defects.

Diastematomyelia (Option A)  is a congenital disorder in which a part of the spinal cord is split, usually at the level of the upper lumbar vertebra.

Craniorachischisis  (Option B) is the anencephaly associated with a continuous bony defect of the spine and exposure of neural tissue.

Holoprosencephaly (Option D) occurs when the procencephalon fails to develop into two hemispheres.

questions.text: A patient with abdominal pain underwent MRCP and findings are shown below, identify the correct match:

choices.text: Chronic pancreatitis with chain of lakes

questions.solution:
MRCP: Atrophic pancreas is seen, with irregular dilatation of pancreatic duct, and multiple intraductal calculi. This “chain of- lakes” appearance is diagnostic of chronic pancreatitis.

Acute pancreatitis is not associated with strictures and obstruction.

CT showing acute interstitial pancreatitis with diffuse swelling of the pancreas  and peripancreatic inflammatory changes (arrows). The pancreas was well perfused without evidence of necrosis. 

CT showing Acute pancreatic necrosis and edema of pancreatic tail and surrounding adipose tissue are visible (arrows).

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient comes to you with the following lesions. He tells you that he used to develop similar lesions since childhood but they always heal without scarring. His father also suffers from a similar condition. Which protein is defective in this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and the image showing superficial blisters are suggestive of epidermolysis bullosa simplex, which is an autosomal dominant condition associated with a defect in K5/K14 proteins. 

Epidermolysis bullosa congenita is a group of congenital mechanobullous disorders that arise after trauma and are common over the hands, feet, elbows, and knees. There are three forms of this condition.

Type Defective protein

Features
Epidermolysis bullosa simplex K5/K14

Intraepidermal blister with split in basal layer

Heals without scarring
Junctional epidermolysis bullosa Laminin

Dermoepidermal junction blister with split in lamina lucida layer

Perioral involvement is  frequent

May heal with scarring
Epidermolysis bullosa dystrophica Collagen VII in anchoring fibrils

Subepidermal tense blisters with defect in sublamina densa

Frequent mucosal involvement

Heal with scarring

questions.text: A 7-month-old child was brought by her mother with complaints of diarrhoea and mucocutaneous lesions as shown in the image. The symptoms have been present since weaning was started. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A child with eczematous rash typically in the perioral and perineal region is characteristic of acrodermatitis enteropathica which is due to secondary zinc deficiency.

It is an autosomal recessive disorder seen in infants due to a defect in the intestinal zinc-specific transporter gene. Oral zinc therapy is the preferred management. It classically presents while weaning from breast milk to formula, which has lower zinc bioavailability than breast milk.

The symptoms are perioral and perineal rashes, periungual dermatitis- Beau’s lines on nails, chronic diarrhea, and alopecia. Children commonly present with symmetrical, eczematous plaques that become vesicular, bullous, pustular, or erosive with characteristic crusting at the edges. The perioral eruption usually spares the upper lip, giving it a U‐shaped or horseshoe‐shaped appearance.

Investigations would reveal low serum zinc. Oral zinc therapy is the treatment of choice (3 mg/kg/24 hour)

Option A: Wiskott Aldrich syndrome is the classical triad of thrombocytopenia, eczema and recurrent pyogenic infections. No history of bleeding rules out this option.

Option C: Epidermolysis bullosa presents as bullous lesions in pressure handling areas.

Option D: In atopic dermatitis usually the lesions will be itchy and distributed in extensor aspects (flexural in adults).

questions.text: Which of the following is unlikely in patients with atheroembolic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Atheroembolic kidney disease is associated with decreased complement levels.

Atheroembolic kidney disease is more frequent in males with a history of diabetes, hypertension, and ischemic heart disease.  Most clinical atheroembolic events follow angiographic procedures, often of the coronary vessels.

It is associated with aortic aneurysms and renal artery stenosis. Systemic embolic manifestations such as fever, abdominal pain, and weight loss are also present, although cutaneous manifestations are more common like livedo reticularis and localized toe gangrene.

The lab findings include:

  • Rising serum creatinine
  • Transient eosinophilia
  • Elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate
  • Hypocomplementemia

Definitive diagnosis depends on kidney biopsy which demonstrates microvessel occlusion with cholesterol crystals that leave a cleft in the vessel as shown below.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with pain and deformity of his toes. The clinical findings are shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical image showing dactylitis, nail changes and telescoping of toes is suggestive of psoriatic arthritis. 

Clinical features of psoriatic arthritis include:

  • Psoriatic nail changes- yellowing and hypertrophy 
  • Dactylitis- inflammation of the toes
  • Telescoping (shortening) of toes due to osteolysis
  • Severe deformity- suggestive of arthritis mutilans
  • Enthesitis- heel pain at the sites of ligament or tendon attachment

Psoriatic arthritis of the hands commonly involves proximal and distal interphalangeal joints (PIP, DIP) and metacarpophalangeal joints (MCP). The image below shows psoriatic arthritis of the hands:

Related Pearl: Joint Involvement in Various Arthritis

 Joint Disorders Joints Commonly Involved

Joints Commonly Spared

 Osteoarthritis

Cervical and lumbosacral spine, PIP, DIP, 1st CMC, hip, knee, 1st MTP, 

 Elbow, Wrist, Ankle, MCP 
Rheumatoid Arthritis Shoulder, Wrist, MCP, PIP, Knee, MTP  DIP 
Ankylosing Spondylitis Sacroiliac joint, intervertebral joints

*Ray distribution: Joint involvement tends to follow a pattern with all of the joints of one finger involved sparing the adjacent finger completely.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents with obesity and short stature, with signs of abnormal masculinization as shown below. Which statement regarding this condition is false?

choices.text: Most common cause is adrenocortical tumor
Hypertension seen here can occasionally lead to heart failure
Generalized obesity is a common finding in younger children.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing round face (moon facies), obesity, abnormal masculinization, and purple skin striae are suggestive of Cushing's syndrome. The most common cause of Cushing's syndrome is prolonged exogenous administration of glucocorticoids, not an adrenocortical tumor.

Cushing's syndrome is characterized excess glucocorticoids that can be due to:

  • Prolonged exogenous administration of glucocorticoids
  • Excess endogenous cortisol secretion:
    • In children <7 years: Most often by a functioning adrenocortical tumor
    • In children >7 years: Most often by an ACTH–producing pituitary adenoma (Cushing's disease)

Important clinical features in children:

  • Obesity or weight gain (most common)
  • Moon facies
  • Purple skin striae
  • Abnormal masculinization (acne, bruising, enlargement of the clitoris in girls)
  • Pubertal developmental delay and amenorrhea in girls
  • Proximal muscle weakness
  • Osteoporosis
  • Hypertension
  • Hyperpigmentation
  • Hypokalemic alkalosis
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Sepsis

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of black stools and black coated tongue as shown in the image. Which of the following drugs is implicated?
questions.solution:
Colloidal bismuth subsalicylate is known to cause blackening of the tongue, dentures and stools.

It combines with trace amounts of sulfur in saliva and colon to form bismuth sulfide. Bismuth sulfide is a highly insoluble black salt. The adverse effect is claimed to be temporary and harmless.

questions.text: While examining a chronic alcoholic patient, you notice the given finding. Which of the following is false regarding it?

choices.text: Occurs due to alterations in the metabolism of estrogen
Presence of even 1 lesion is abnormal
Commonly seen over the superior vena cava territory
Compression results in blanching followed by reappearance after release

questions.solution:
The given image shows spider telangiectasia and the presence of >2 to 3 of these are considered abnormal.

Spider telangiectasias are dilated arterioles with a prominent central arteriole with radiating vessels appearing in the shape of a spider. They are generally seen in the superior vena cava territory. Compression results in blanching followed by reappearance after the release of pressure. They occur due to a hyperestrogenic state which is caused by defective estrogen metabolism in liver cirrhosis.

Clinical features seen in cirrhosis include:

  • Spider telangiectasias
  • Palmar erythema
  • Terry's nails - pallor of the proximal nail bed
  • Clubbing
  • Gynaecomastia
  • Caput medusae - dilated abdominal veins.
  • Parotid enlargement

The image below shows Terry's nails.

questions.text: A new mother brings her 2-day-old baby to the pediatric OPD with the following skin findings on his back. Which of the following statements is false regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Mongolian spots. The coloration is due to the arrested migration of melanocytes within the deep dermis and to the epidermis. It is not due to increased melanocytes.

These are congenital macular areas of blue‐grey pigmentation of varying size and shape located on the lumbosacral area in normal infants. The lesion develops in-utero, increases during infancy, and then diminishes. Sometimes may occasionally persist into adult life.

These are associated with Down syndrome and congenital hemangioma. Extensive Mongolian spots have been associated with Hurler syndrome and GM1 gangliosidosis type 1.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant lady is referred to the dermatology OPD with the given condition. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This pregnant lady has chloasma or a mask of pregnancy. In non-pregnant women, it is called melasma. 

Chloasma is very common in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy and is most marked in brunettes.

It is due to increased levels of estrogen and progesterone, stimulating the activity of melanocytes. Histopathology shows no increase in number but hyper-functional melanocytes. It resolves on its own after pregnancy.

Melasma is the most common cause of chronic facial melanosis. It is manifested by hyperpigmented macules that become more pronounced after sun exposure. Hypermelanosis affects mainly the upper lip, the malar regions, forehead, and chin. It is more common in women between 20-40 years. It is frequently seen in women on oral contraceptives.

Wood's lamp examination is useful to differentiate the level of pigmentation and treatment response:  

  • Epidermal melasma- shows enhanced color contrast 
  • Dermal melasma- shows less color contrast (more resistant to treatment)
  • Mixed melasma.

Melasma is more chronic and requires treatment with depigmenting agents like:

  • Kligman's triple combination - topical hydroquinone + tretinoin + corticosteroid compound cream (first line)
  • Hydroquinone (reduces tyrosinase activity)
  • Kojic acid (tyrosinase inhibitor)
  • Chemical peels

Related Pearl: Key Chart to help differentiate lesions on face

Key Chart to help Differentiate Lesions on face

 

The following images show the findings in -

  • Melasma

 

  • Rosacea

 

  • Butterfly-shaped malar rash in SLE 

 

  • Acne

 

  • Nevus of Ota

 

  • Portwine stain

 

  • Infantile hemangioma

questions.text: A dermatologist is consulted regarding a 20-year old patient who underwent surgery for intestinal obstruction last week. Which of the following is the cause of hair loss in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given image is characteristic of trichotillomania. It is an obsessive-compulsive disorder characterized by compulsive hair pulling. Ingestion of the plucked hair is called trichophagia. Rarely, the resulting hairball called trichobezoar can cause intestinal obstruction. 

The characteristic features are,

  • Varying lengths of hair and absence of complete hair loss in the patch
  • Orentreich or Friar Tuck or Tonsure sign: Loss of central area (easier to pull) and sparing of margins of the scalp.
  • Broken hair shafts
  • No scarring.

Histopathological examination shows,

  • No inflammation 
  • Peribulbar, intraepithelial and perifollicular hemorrhages 
  • Intrafollicular pigment casts.

Trichotillosis is the newer term as it is not a 'mania'. It shares some features with the OCD spectrum of disorders. It is usually associated with other psychiatric conditions.

Option A: Alopecia areata shows well-circumscribed patches of complete hair loss with sparing of white hair, as shown below.

Option B: Pseudopelade of Brocq is a scarring alopecia that produces small round or oval patches of smooth alopecia, described as footprints in the snow.

Option C: Telogen effluvium can occur 2-3 months after systemic stress such as surgery or illness, but it causes diffuse hair loss, not patchy as in this patient.

questions.text: What is the clinical procedure being performed?

choices.text: Femoral IV access for fluid transfusion

questions.solution:
The above image shows intraosseous cannulation for fluid transfusion in the anterior proximal tibia.

The intraosseous route is an alternative to the intravenous (IV) route in the transfusion of fluids in shock. 

  • The marrow of long bones has a rich network of vessels that drain into a central venous canal, emissary veins, and ultimately the central circulation.
  • So, the bone marrow functions as a non-collapsible venous access route.

Intraosseous cannulation is recommended for patients in whom IV access proves difficult or unattainable. (e.g., in cardiopulmonary arrest). In such a case, if venous access is not available within 1 min, an intraosseous needle should be placed in the anterior proximal tibia.

Insertion sites for intraosseous infusion: 

  • In the proximal tibia, 1-2 cm anteromedial from the tibial tuberosity
  • Distal tibia at the junction of the medial malleolus and the shaft of the tibia
  • Distal one-third of the femur

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl develops the following lesions after a camping trip. They are mildly itchy. In which condition are they characteristically seen?
questions.solution:
This image shows typical target lesions, characteristically seen in erythema multiforme.

It is also called an iris or bull's eye lesion and typically consists of 3 zones as follows:

  1. Central area of dusky erythema or purpura
  2. Middle paler zone of edema
  3. Outer ring of erythema with a well-defined edge

Atypical target lesions with only 2 zones may be seen in Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN). 

Related Pearl: Glossary of important skin lesions

Glossary of Important Skin Lesions

Lesion

Description

Alopecia

Absence of hair from a normally hairy area

Aphtha

A small ulcer of the mucosa

Atrophy

Loss of tissue from one or more of the epidermis, dermis or subcutaneous tissues

Burrow

A small tunnel in the skin that houses a parasite, such as the scabies acarus

Callus

A localized hyperplasia of the stratum corneum

Cellulitis

An inflammation of cellular tissue, particularly purulent inflammation of the deep dermis and subcutaneous tissue

Comedo

A plug of keratin and sebum in a dilated pilosebaceous orifice

Crusts (scabs)

Crusts consist of dried serum and other exudates

Cyst

Any closed cavity or sac (normal or abnormal) with an epithelial, endothelial or membranous lining and containing fluid or semi‐solid material

Ecchymosis

A macular area of hemorrhage more than 1 cm (bruise) in diameter

Erosion

A loss of epidermis, which heals without scarring. It commonly follows a blister.

Erythema

Redness of the skin produced by vascular congestion or increased perfusion

Excoriation

Loss of skin substance, specifically produced by scratching

Exfoliation

The splitting off of the epidermal keratin in scales or sheets

Fibrosis

The formation of excessive fibrous tissue

Fissure

Any linear gap or slit in the skin surface

Fistula

An abnormal passage from a deep structure, such as a hollow viscus, to the skin surface or between two structures

Gangrene

Death of tissue, usually due to loss of blood supply

Guttate lesions

Small round or oval lesions distributed as a ‘shower’ of droplets. Usually applied to a form of psoriasis

Hematoma

A localized tumor‐like collection of blood

Keratoderma

A horny thickening of the skin

Lichenification

Thickening of the epidermis (and to some extent also of the dermis) in response to prolonged rubbing

Macule

A flat circumscribed, non‐palpable lesion that differs in color from the surrounding skin. It can be of any color or shape. A macule is <1 cm in diameter, larger lesions are a patch.

Maculopapular

Rash consisting of both macules and papules

Milium

A tiny white cyst containing lamellated keratin

Nodule*

A solid palpable lesion in the dermis or subcutis, which can be observed as an elevation or can be palpated. It is >0.5 cm in diameter.

Papule

An elevated solid lesion that is <1 cm in diameter.

Petechia

A punctate hemorrhagic spot, approximately 1–2 mm in diameter.

Plaque

An elevated circumscribed lesion >1 cm diameter; its surface is usually flat. Plaques may form from coalesced papules.

Poikiloderma

The association of cutaneous pigmentation, and telangiectasia.

Pustule

A circumscribed lesion that contains purulent material. 

Pyoderma

Any purulent skin disease

Scale

Scale is a flat plate or flake-like lesion desquamated of stratum corneum.

Scar

Replacement by fibrous tissue of another tissue that has been destroyed by injury or disease

An atrophic scar is thin and wrinkled.

A hypertrophic scar is elevated, with excessive growth of fibrous tissue.

Sclerosis

Diffuse or circumscribed induration of the subcutaneous tissues. It may also involve the dermis, when the overlying epidermis may be atrophic. It is characteristically seen in scleroderma.

Sinus

A cavity or track with a blind ending

Target lesions

These are <3 cm in diameter and have three or more zones, usually a central area of dusky erythema or purpura, a middle paler zone of edema, and an outer ring of erythema with a well‐defined edge.

Tumor

Literally a swelling; the term is used to imply enlargement of the tissues by normal or pathological material, or cells that form a mass. 

Ulcer (of skin)

A loss of dermis and epidermis, often with loss of the underlying tissues
Vesicles and Bullae

 A vesicle is a circumscribed elevation <1 cm in diameter that contains fluid

Bullae are >1 cm in diameter
Wheal  A transient elevation of the skin due to dermal and hypodermal, often pale centrally with an erythematous rim; it is the characteristic lesion of urticaria.

 *While Rook's textbook of Dermatology,9th edition mention nodule as >0.5 cm. Some authors define nodules as >1 cm.
